content: I'd like to show you how I turn this into this
in only three hours hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic
crafts so this episode I wanted to really challenge myself I was thinking
about how I've spent the past you know almost two years with this channel
trying to learn and develop techniques and research tools that make terrain
building more efficient and faster while resulting in good results I've kind of
done a bunch of videos that show different techniques or tools and stuff
separately and you know some that you know mix it all together but I wondered
if I could really take the speed like the time-saving techniques and tools and
cram them into a speed build and what I mean by that is I wanted to know if I
could take raw XPS insulation foam and build a simple yet detailed house for my
table in a very limited amount of time by combining the techniques I've talked
about in the past and utilizing some of these tools that I've been promoting I
managed to build this simple well that simple but this like little cottage that
is fairly detailed with brickwork and you know wood and a door and a chimney
in three hours and I and I mean three hours including breaking down the raw
foam building it painting it 3 hours of work it did take slightly longer
throughout the day simply because I was also filming and had to have that you
know take up a little bit extra time and of course there was some drying time
involved but that was fairly minimal even if you included the drying time of
Mod Podge paint and wash and the other thing I would have completed
this build in like five hours pretty crazy
and you gotta say I'm pretty impressed with the results this isn't the best
building that I've ever made but it's pretty good and while some of the
techniques I utilized here aren't what I would do in a project where I was
putting in a lot of effort I think it's a great compromise for effort and time
versus quality and if you need to make a whole village you want several buildings
for an encounter or for wargaming or whatever you can't utilize those high
detail time like long time techniques you need to kind of speed through stuff
so I'm gonna prove to you that you can sit back relax let's take a look at how
I built this building start to finish three freaking hours I'm still pretty
surprised so started with a plan real simple plan and I want to work breaking
down some foam out of this big rough ugly piece of insulation foam using the
procs on table and shifting lands calm guider pro to break pieces down into
nice clean usable pieces I'm making these about I don't know I think as well
as centimeter thick for the walls but honestly just eyeballed it and same with
the pieces for the roof again just eyeballed them a little bit thinner and
we need a couple of strips now here I'm gonna break down the walls rip them at
two inches because I wanted the walls to be 2 inches tall and then just
cross-cutting them to have nice 90-degree square corners and here I'm
laying out the front and back wall and just doing some quick layout of center
using the thickness of the wall to find the halfway point diagonally go point to
point and here you notice I don't even measure anything I just cut one angle
and keep flipping the pieces so that they end up exactly the same and using
those as a guide now I'm going to use the green stuff
calm rolling pin to do the brick and to keep things straight I'm gonna use these
silicon guides that they had actually sent me that I didn't realize that they
could be used for this when I made the last video about the rolling pins I
thought they were just for gauging thickness of clay or green stuff but
they actually work great as guides to keep your rolling pin straight and you
can see here it's taking just moments to do this brickwork now because the
printed back for an odd shape I just put the guide on one end and that was enough
now that I got all four walls just hot gluing them together I kind of used this
square on my cutting mat to kind of eyeball square once in a while but I was
just going really really fast here and just banging it together as quick as I
could now the roof piece again just eyeballed the length cut that eyeball
the overhang and cut that and then I'm gonna cut the second roof piece a little
bit bigger specifically the thickness of the
material bigger so that it can have that overlap at the top and then I'm just
going to hot glue those both in place
now I need some timbers to cover the edge of the styrofoam that doesn't have
brickwork and just dress up the whole thing so I'm just using cut off that was
the same thickness of the wall and slicing a whole bunch of really thin
strips that I'm here using a pencil to do some exaggerated wood grain you could
do this even quicker with a wire brush but once in a while I like that more
exaggerated cartoonish kind of wood grain and here just hot gluing them on
the corners letting them run wild and then you just quickly cut them off with
a knife decided I wanted one in the middle and
again didn't measure just eyeball and hear some horizontal cross-bracing again
no measuring just hold the piece up cut your angle hot glue throw it on real
fast now the hot glue to put this stuff on is definitely the fastest way to do
it if you're doing a speed build like this where you just need things to be
locked in quickly so you can keep going hot glue is great it has the downside of
giving you a lot of wisps that kind of get all over everything so if you have
time to spare I recommend maybe using you know tacky
glue or PVA glue to hold this stuff in place but if you want to rock out a
whole bunch of these real fast hot glue is gonna be your best friend now here
I'm gonna make a little door I have a little jig that I use as a template for
whipping up quick doors just draw in some wood green with the pencil and yeah
real simple farmhouse door but it is too thick so I'm gonna take it over to the
proc saw and just shave it down so it's super super thin and I'm gonna glue it
right in place here I'm just eyeballing how I want to do the door frame and
thought maybe these timbers would be too big and they kind of are but speed build
just just going with it and I decided that before these two pieces but up to
each other that I wanted to kind of cut the edge of it to make it look less like
a factory cut and I'm doing that on the top piece as well so that there's kind
of groove in between the two Timbers and then I'm going to go around with a nail
file and break the edges of all these little wood strips so that they look
kind of rough and I'm being really aggressive with it actually taking out
chunks in spots also where there's the overlap using the pencil just to draw in
another wood grain so it blends in a little bit better and you can see I'm
ripping out big chunks here because like I said I want it to look rough and
just kind of rugged-looking here decided it needed one more kind of support
member and again just eyeball knife cut in place push it into the glue break the
edge here and deciding to put one on the back which you'll see later that I end
up removing because I decide I want to put a chimney thereafter so now I need
something for the roof and the very fastest way you can do this is big wood
planks shingles are great and they look better and they're more historically
accurate or thatch roofing but big just strip shingles is the fastest way to do
a foam roof so here I'm just cutting a bunch of thin strips that are 5/8 of an
inch wide so that there have about an eighth of an inch of overlap when I
install them and leave about a half-inch remaining I'm using my knife to cut one
edge of each of these and it kind of wavy cut so it has that kind of live
edge look so it looks like it you know was cut from a tree and again quick
pencil woodgrain to kind of dress these up a little bit now I'm just hot gluing
these in place and overlapping them about an eighth of an inch and I
probably should have cut these a little bit thinner normally I would cut them a
little bit thinner these are kind of bulky but like I said this is a speed
build and there was no going back really on
things it was just go go go you see here I have both sides done and I'm just
making a cap to hide the seam this strip I did cut quite a bit thinner so that it
would crease and fold nicely then you'd run the wood grain in place because it's
easier on and off on this ticular piece now you see I ran all
those pieces wild just overhung them don't take too much time you know
lining them up because you just cut them off easily after and there you go
everything is flush and to hide the edge I'm gonna put another layer of timber to
act kind of as a fascia board just using some leftover pieces from the roof and
cutting them in half and hot gluing them in place and you can see here I just ran
it wild and then cut the mitre angle in place it's a little bit easier to
eyeball once it's on and when you're doing these speed builds don't waste too
much time measuring you got to learn which things you can just very quickly
hold in place and cut as you go and once you kind of master that and get
comfortable doing that you're gonna save yourself a lot of time now here to dress
up the door I'm just taking some off cut in strips and using a bit of tacky glue
to do some cross bracing on the drove on the door and I like to always add these
little support timber sticking out the fronts and backs of buildings I'm not
sure why I do because they're kind of vulnerable little pieces but I think it
adds a bit to the to the look here so I put one of those in place
now I here's where I decided I want to
Tim nee and this is a chimney that I made in like three minutes I just ripped
a cube strip on the procs on table hues the green stuff roller to give it the
brick texture and it was made in like under a minute now here I'm cutting out
all the stuff so that it can you know be put in place obviously you know you
could put this chimney in first but hey I was just kind of making things up as I
went along cut out the groove hot glue it in place
and then it's done and this video is sped up but really this chimney took
like three minutes to make it's crazy with the procs on and the green stuff
rollers it's unbelievable how fast you can make this stuff so now I'm just
putting a little stone cap on the top and I decided it needed a little actual
inner chimney so I just use a little bead cut a little groove put it in place
with some glue done real real simple at this point I'm probably had two hours in
on this build here I'm just coating out all the wood
first in a very medium kind of brown I actually was pretty much out of all
Browns I only had a really really dark espresso Brown so I mixed it with some
white to lighten it up and just went to town brushing out all the timbers and
not being careful definitely over brushing onto the stonework which
doesn't matter whatsoever and here I'm gonna go in with some medium gray into
the stonework and I was doing this when the brown was actually still wet so all
that over brushing actually I blended in with the gray and it actually gave the
gray a bit of kind of natural variation so yeah it's like a little bit of a real
fast wet blend here and you can see I added
some little Timbers on the top that are a different color I had some holes I
wanted to cover in a spot where I didn't like the timber so I decided to add a
little that a patchwork would and I really
liked it so I added a few more pieces and I painted them a different color of
Browns so that they look newer same with the door and here I'm just doing gray
dry brushing over all of the stonework and the timbers same color doesn't
matter keep it real simple just hit all those edges with you know the light gray
and here I'm going on to the stone with one final quick dry brushing of
off-white to hit the real high points and here and the magic stuff the real
simple quick and easy black wash over everything getting all those nooks and
crannies really bring out that stone texture from the roller and you can see
I am not shy with the wash and you should not be either just get that
sucker covered let it dry and once that's dry you can spray it with
polyurethane and you're good to go and there you have it guys
that video was sped up but not by that much and you can really see that this
thing came together incredibly fast I just powered through it didn't take
time to think about anything just went and build and just did it just go go go
go go get it done you can do it too so by utilizing some of these tools that
I've been promoting like the stuff from shifting Lance comm the green stuff
rollers the procs on tools them all these things together combined create a
system in which you can build buildings incredibly fast if you want to now if
you're less experienced it might still take a little bit longer but the reality
is you can still build one of these things start to finish in a day I
promise you you can if you utilize the techniques that I am using and some of
the tools so on that note if you want to pick up any of the tools and supplies
that I used in this build you can head over to Blackmagic crafty a there I have
my essential equipment store which is all my Amazon affiliate links that will
lead you to stuff like the proxxon cutter or the Mod Podge and various
other tools that I use but those are the only things that are available on Amazon
green stuff WorldCom to pick up those textured rolling pins and silicone
guides that I use depending on when you watch this video you may still have a
chance to utilize the five percent off discount code that green stuff world set
up for black magic crafts the link will be in the description I can't remember
the expiry date I believe it's October 20th so if you
get it in time good stuff there's also a referral program that you
can put in an email address of who referred you so I will put the black
magic craft email in the description for you to enter for that as well of course
if you found this video useful hit that like button drop me a comment below if
you are attempting this and you're having trouble and you got any questions
that you want to bounce off me or a group of really cool crafters think
about joining the black magic craft fellowship it's the private Facebook
community that you can get access to by supporting me on patreon so head over to
the patreon take a look there I hope that this inspires you to build more
buildings and to not be intimidated by building foam buildings in detail is
possible to do it quickly and easily I promise you that
